title.value: Functional connectivity subtypes associate robustly with ASD diagnosis
title.justification: The title of the paper is clearly stated at the beginning of the document, highlighting the primary focus of the research.
title.quote: Functional connectivity subtypes associate robustly with ASD diagnosis

extractions.description: The study investigates the association of functional connectivity subtypes with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) diagnosis using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data. The paper examines the robustness and generalizability of these connectivity subtypes in relation to clinical diagnosis of ASD, leveraging data-driven clustering methods for analysis.

type.justification: The paper reports on experimental analysis using fMRI data to evaluate the robustness of functional connectivity subtypes in ASD, indicating an empirical approach.
type.quote: Here, we show that a simple hierarchical cluster analysis can robustly relate a given individual and brain network to a connectivity subtype, but that continuous assignments are more robust than discrete ones.

name.justification: The paper focuses on brain imaging and analyzing functional connectivity related to autism, which falls under neuroscience.
name.quote: The authors examine autism subtypes using functional connectivity data derived from magnetic resonance imaging.

name.justification: The paper revolves around investigating functional connectivity subtypes and their relation to ASD.
name.quote: Yet, the robustness and generalizability of functional connectivity subtypes is unknown.

name.justification: The primary condition being studied and analyzed in relation to functional brain connectivity in the paper is Autism Spectrum Disorder.
name.quote: We then investigate whether fully data driven FC subtypes are associated with a clinical diagnosis of ASD.

name.justification: The dataset name is mentioned as being used for the discovery analysis, providing the foundational data for the study.
name.quote: The discovery sample consisted of imaging data from the ABIDE 1 dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange: Towards a Large-Scale Evaluation of the Intrinsic Brain Architecture in Autism
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the paper where the ABIDE 1 dataset is introduced and discussed, hence providing foundational reference for its use.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Di Martino A. 2014. The Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange: Towards a Large-Scale Evaluation of the Intrinsic Brain Architecture in Autism

name.justification: The ABIDE 2 dataset is used in the study for replication analysis, validating the findings from the discovery sample.
name.quote: The replication sample consisted of imaging data from the ABIDE 2 dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Enhancing Studies of the Connectome in Autism Using the Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange II
referenced_paper_title.justification: Provided as the reference title in the paper for the ABIDE 2 dataset, contributing to the study's analysis and replication framework.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Di Martino A. 2017. Enhancing Studies of the Connectome in Autism Using the Autism Brain Imaging Data Exchange II

name.justification: The HNU 1 dataset is used to evaluate the stability of continuous subtype assignments, contributing to the robustness analysis in the paper.
name.quote: The second longitudinal test sample consisted of individuals in the general population Hangzhou Normal University dataset (http://dx.doi.org/10.15387/fcp_indi.corr.hnu1) released by the consortium for reliability and reproducibility.

referenced_paper_title.value: An open science resource for establishing reliability and reproducibility in functional connectomics
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title facilitates the use of the HNU 1 dataset in assessing connectivity and reliability as mentioned in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Zuo XN, Anderson JS, Bellec P, Birn RM, Biswal BB, Blautzik J, Breitner JCS, Buckner RL, Calhoun VD, Castellanos FX, Chen A. 2014. An open science resource for establishing reliability and reproducibility in functional connectomics.
